sections.heading: What is PF (Provident Fund)?
content: The Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) is a government-backed retirement savings plan. Both employees and employers contribute each month, and the funds grow with interest.
EPF also includes the Employees' Pension Scheme (EPS) and Employees' Deposit Linked Insurance (EDLI), providing retirement savings, pensions, and insurance.

sections.heading: Who Needs to Register for PF?

points: Businesses with 20 or more employees
Corporations, LLCs, partnerships, and sole proprietorships
Factories, shops, and other establishments
Note: Businesses with less than 20 employees can voluntarily register.

points: Employer registers using business PAN on the EPFO portal
Upload documents and digitally sign the application
EPFO reviews and issues PF Establishment Code within 7-15 business days
Employee contributes 12% of basic salary
Employer contributes 12% of basic salary (split between EPF and EPS)
8.33% goes to Employee Pension Scheme, remaining to EPF
Pay PF contributions monthly by the 15th
File monthly returns (ECR)
Maintain employee records
Update employees' KYC regularly
Fines up to 100% of unpaid contributions
Interest on late payments
Possible legal action
Business closure
Do startups need PF registration? Yes, if they have 20 or more employees.
Can businesses register voluntarily? Yes, businesses with less than 20 employees can register.
Does PF cover contract employees? Yes.
Which salary components are included? Basic salary and dearness allowance.
Can employees opt out? Only if their salary exceeds legal limits.
Does PF apply to foreign employees? Yes, under social security agreements.
